messages.content: 9-1-1, what's your emergency?
He's been stabbed really bad.
What's your address, ma'am?
It's 318 McCrae Street.
Is he breathing, ma'am?
No, there's blood everywhere.
The person who stabbed him, is he there?
No.
Take a deep breath, okay? How old is he?
He's 26.
What's your name, ma'am?
Mary.
Ma'am, I need you to answer these questions so we can get help on the way.
Is he completely alert? Where is he injured?
In his stomach. There's so much blood.
Is there more than one wound?
I only see one wound.
Okay. I'm sending paramedics now. Stay on the line. I'll tell you exactly what to do.
If there's anything penetrating, do not pull it out, okay?
I'm not. I know that.
He hit his head against the stairs, so I don't want to move him.
Okay. That's right. Don't move him. Just keep him still.
Don't let him have anything to eat or drink. It may make him sick or cause problems for the doctors.
Do you know where the person is who stabbed him?
No, he's gone.
Is there somebody else there with you besides him?
Yes, my roommate.
Tell them to get a clean dry cloth, okay?
He's gone. I don't know where he went.
Ma'am, I need you to get a clean dry cloth to try to stop the bleeding.
Okay, I'll use my shirt.
Press it down firmly on the wound and don't lift it up.
Can I tie it down tight?
Just press it down firmly. Don't tie it.
Did it happen inside the house?
Yes, it happened inside.
Which one is the person that's cut? Your roommate or your fiancé?
My fiancé.
Is he still alert?
I can't tell. His eyes are rolling back.
Keep talking to him. Is he breathing?
Yes, he's breathing.
Do you see his chest going up and down?
Yes, I do.
Just confirm your address, ma'am. Is there an apartment number?
No, it's a house.
Okay. Stay on the line and keep pressing on the wound. Help is on the way.
